thread.title: Ticker: Ferris State's Jason Vander Laan sets QB rush record
thread.title_full: Ticker: Ferris State's Jason Vander Laan sets QB rush record

author: freep.com
title: Ticker: Ferris State's Jason Vander Laan sets QB rush record
text:
MORE
If you think of the great running quarterbacks, guys like Cam Newton, Tim Tebow and Denard Robinson may pop to mind.
But if you're thinking of the most prolific running QB, you'd better think about Ferris State Jason Vander Laan.
On Saturday, he became the all-time leading rusher for a signal caller in NCAA history with 5,218 yards. In the 38-17 win over Ohio Dominican, Vander Laan broke the record with a 53-yard TD run in the second quarter. He finished the game with 161 yards on the ground and two touchdowns to go with 151 yards through the air.
"This was literally the last thing I would have told you (would have happened) when I was a freshman," Vander Laan said Saturday in an interview on SportsCenter.
Vander Laan is 38-2 in his career at Ferris State. Last year, he won the Harlon Hill Trophy as the best player in Division II as a junior. It's the same award Lions running back Joique Bell won at Wayne State.
Wofford's Shawn Graves had the previous record of 5,128, set in 1992. The 6-0 Bulldogs have four games left on the schedule so who knows where Vander Laan's total will be at season's end.
U-M can't win pity
USA TODAY's Dan Wolken puts out a Misery Index to rank the 10 most agonized fan bases of the week.
As you may imagine, Michigan ranks very high on this list this week. But they're somehow only No. 2.
How can that be, considering how U-M lost to rival MSU on Saturday?
Wolken: "There is one thing preventing Michigan from being No. 1 on this list. The Misery Index, see, is about more than just one week or one play. And though the ending to Saturday's 27-23 loss to Michigan State was one of the all-time gut punches and will forever be part of this rivalry, it is undeniable that the Wolverines are ahead of schedule under Jim Harbaugh."
The top spot went to Ole Miss, which lost at unbeaten Memphis. Three other Big Ten schools were mentioned: Indiana, Penn State and Purdue.
Compiled from staff reports by Kirkland Crawford: kcrawford @freepress.com.
